item.title: Stylized Trim Practice : Made with Grabdoc by Michael Kinsey
item.description:
Made with Blender, GrabDoc addon and Substance painter.
Decided to get into stylised art more recently for fun and made this trim as a benchmark asset to test the performance of a free Blender Trims and tile-ables creation add-on I was helping my friend Ethan Simon develop. (https://www.artstation.com/razed)

I have done a video breakdown of what the does on the Dinusty YouTube channel here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7pMoSrkd1FQ
And will be showing more content with it soon.

I hope you like the material and find the add-on useful

item.title: End of July update: by Michael Kinsey
item.content:encoded:
Hey all!


Been a while since my last blog post so I thought I would give an update on what has been going on.
Before I start going on about myself though I want to give a shout out to some awesome work I have found recently.



Portfolio Feature:

This blogs portfolio feature will be Igor Elovikov: https://www.artstation.com/elovikov¬†

He doesn't have much up but the quality of what he has up and the fact he is giving away his nodes for free is really awesome!
I have started personally using these in my material art workflows and highly recommend people check them out!


Content Showcase:
And I want to share some learning content that my good Friend Duard has started making for his YouTube channel showing how he makes hard surface assets in Fusion360.
Anyone interested in learning Fusion should check it out:¬†https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WmqJLxPqiAc


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Onto the update:


Working for Black Matter:
I am happy to announce that as of the 1st of July I started working at Black Matter games on Hell Let Loose!
I look forward to show you what I am working on during my time here at Black Matter when the time is right.
https://www.hellletloose.com/


XP Article on Leading teams remotely:
Since the last update I have had the privilege to be featured in an XP article on leading teams remotely:
https://www.exp-points.com/michael-dekogon-warthogs-gym-ue4


Freelance Podcast:
I also talked about Freelancing with some good friends and ex Dekogon colleagues who have all had their fair amount of experience freelancing so anyone wanting to get more insight from them I would recommend checking out the episode:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XLDEVtHNTbE



Artstation Magazing - Guide to Freelancing:
And additionally was featured along side some of them in Artstations Guide to Freelancing article.
I highly recommend checking it out as a lot of work was put into it and it includes knowledge from many very talented freelancers in the industry: https://magazine.artstation.com/2020/06/the-artstation-guide-to-freelancing/



Blender GrabDoc Addon:
I had the privilege to work with a really talented tools programmer to realise and streamline a pipeline I have been working on using Blenders features to efficiently make tileables and trims.
Check out Ethans Artstation here:
https://www.artstation.com/razed¬†
And the addon can be found here:
https://gumroad.com/l/grabdoc¬†

I made a video showcasing the features of Grabdoc over on the Dinusty empire channel: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7pMoSrkd1FQ

I am currently working on tutorials showing this addon being used in industry standard workflows .
And the first example material I made will be going live soon, and all the source content will be put on my artstation store for free.
First example material wip:

Lastly I have also started some Substance texturing utilities, new content and my next portfolio piece and will be updating my blog showing those and other things soon.

Its been a hectic few months but I'm all settled into my new place and work now so am happy to say I will be able to do more updates more regularly moving forward.

If you made it this far, thanks for reading and I hope all is going well your side.
Would appreciate feedback on the addon or my material above if anyone has any.
Thanks and stay safe üëç

item.title: Forest Biome Materials by Michael Kinsey
item.description:
Here is a collection of materials a Forest biome I did for a client back in 2018.
Unfortunately the project was cancelled but I enjoyed the process of making so many materials for an open world project.

All materials were done 100% in substance Designer and rendered in Unreal Engine 4.
Property of Cat Code Games ltd

item.title: WARTHOGS GYM - Working with remote teams by Michael Kinsey
item.description:
Had the privilege to answer some questions for an article on the Warthogs Gym environment and on what it is like to manage a team of artists all over the world. Huge thanks to Kem Yaralioglu for the opportunity and to Clinton Crumpler for allowing me to give people a look behind the curtain of my time working with Dekogon as a Lead Environment artist.

And thankf to the talented team I worked with for the awesome work on this environment!

https://www.exp-points.com/michael-dekogon-warthogs-gym-ue4

item.title: May update: Joining the Empire and GDD Podcast ep:52 by Michael Kinsey
item.content:encoded:
Had the privilege to join Alex Beddows on episode 52 of his GDD podcast and talk about some interesting topics.
Was a blast and huge thanks to Alex for having me on as a guest.
Also thanks to Duard Mostert for the Astronaut picture.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Listen on Spotify ‚Øà https://open.spotify.com/show/7spDMpMZJ9dr3Ziu8bRwCA

Listen on SoundCloud ‚Øà https://soundcloud.com/gamedevdiscussion

Listen on iTunes ‚Øà https://podcasts.apple.com/gb/podcast/game-dev-discussion/id1459400002

Listen on YouTube ‚Øà https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCKfTBvcsO9Kw0b5EVuf4CJQ

Support the podcast on Patreon ‚Øà https://www.patreon.com/GDD_Podcast

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

With this also comes the news that I have been lucky enough to join with the Dinusty empire as a partner.
And am working to make learning content for the community starting with the recent video on making semi procedural edge wear in Blender.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Join the discord here: https://discord.com/invite/5Qe3Skg¬†

item.title: Artstation Course: Intro to Blender for Game Art Pipelines by Michael Kinsey

Intro


Procedural previs material creation


Basic Modelling, Shading and UV's


Procedural Modelling With Modifiers


Viewport Shading Overview


Utilising Modifiers to help with standard workflows

item.title: Substance Simple Stones Node by Michael Kinsey
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

If you wanna skip the Intro; the link to the substance node is at the bottom, grab it for free :)

I learned a lot in 2019 and all the time I was learning and experimenting with things, whenever I would show a friend or colleague the end product, They would say:

"You should sell that!" and ¬†"You should make a portfolio post about that" and so on.

And I would freak out at the extra time it would take to make nice renders and clean everything up to a point I would be happy to show publicly.

Especially as that time is added on top of what I have already spent on the task, plus full time work.

So the product of all my personal tinkering last year is collecting virtual dust on my hard drive only to be used internally never to be seen publicly.

But my new years resolution this year is to start showing my work.
It is not doing any good sitting on my hard drive only to be used sometimes, and I feel it can do more good in others hands.
They can take where I left off and build on it even if I have moved on due to my eclectic curiosity.

So starting with this post I will start sharing random game art tid bits I have created, or completely stumbled on by chance.
I want to share them all; or at least as much as possible, so here goes nothing...


Simple Stones Node:
(Names aren't my strong suit)

For a long time I have used a simple method for creating stones utilising A cells node plugged into a small series of flood fills. And recently some node updates to designer made this much cheaper and simpler to setup.

Essentially by taking any heightmap and using the inverse of the AO to control where stones generate.
And driving the stones shape from a simple Cells node.

Then using some Flood fills to make the shaping and the mask from the AO and you have a strong base for stones:

And you can tweak the scale of the stones by tweaking the scale of the Cells node:

However doing this every time I want stones in a project has become tedious:

(Old material of mine)


So I decided to collate these nodes and combine them with some extra nodes to make a simple stones Node for use in all my projects moving forward:

And the result of this simple graph comes this:
Which is a simple to use node that can be daisy chained to naturally layer multiple layers of stones on top of eachother:

Which can be customised for use in fully procedural materials:

This uses no custom nodes but probably could be optimised more, but for my use sake I feel this will do a good enough job for now.
If I make any changes to it in future I will make an update post.

Lastly I wanna say that I will be giving this away for free on my Artstation store page:
https://artstn.co/m/DRA9

And as it uses no custom nodes feel free to use it in whatever graphs you want.
And I have also provided the demo files and original SBS for the custom node for anyone who wants to change or add anything in the node.

Hope you found this helpful :)

item.title: Artstation | Beneath The Waves Challenge Submission by Michael Kinsey
item.description:
My submission to the artstation Beneath the waves competition.
https://www.artstation.com/contests/beneath-the-waves/challenges/37/submissions/25362
It was a great learning experience since I had never done an underwater scene before.
I also started very late into the competition due to another competition and illness, however am quite happy with the outcome.
This whole environment took about two weeks to create. Using a wide array of software packages from open source to industry standard.

item.title: Substance Challenge 16 | Train Track Material by Michael Kinsey
item.description:
This was my first Polycount Challenge entry, Made 100% in Designer.
Some renders in UE4, some from Designer viewport 2048*2048 PBR textures.

Was a blast working on this, pushing designer until my PC literally can't handle the graph anymore.
